instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00850: What is 820-00850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1989: What is A1989? A1989 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2018, 2019 with EMC 3124, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00850..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid Damage to <SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_CPU</SIGNAL> <CAPACITOR>C7214</CAPACITOR> - 5v no Boot
threads.message:
Have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 13" Pro 4 Thunderbolt Port.

Liquid damage to <CAPACITOR>C7214</CAPACITOR> only, was totally burned out with burning electrical smell. Shorting to ground for sure.

Getting 5.1v on USB

No liquid to anything else.

Fried CPU?

Cheers

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid Damage to <SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_CPU</SIGNAL> <CAPACITOR>C7214</CAPACITOR> - 5v no Boot
threads.message:
Very likely.
What is the ohm resistance to ground on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid Damage to <SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_CPU</SIGNAL> <CAPACITOR>C7214</CAPACITOR> - 5v no Boot
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid Damage to <SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_CPU</SIGNAL> <CAPACITOR>C7214</CAPACITOR> - 5v no Boot
threads.message: Remove <CHIP>U7210</CHIP>/20 (one by one) and see if short disappears..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid Damage to <SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_CPU</SIGNAL> <CAPACITOR>C7214</CAPACITOR> - 5v no Boot
threads.message:
Tried removing one at a time and then both, 

<CHIP>U7210</CHIP> Only 1.7 ohm
<CHIP>U7220</CHIP> Only 1.7 ohm
Both Off - 1.6 ohm

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid Damage to <SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_CPU</SIGNAL> <CAPACITOR>C7214</CAPACITOR> - 5v no Boot
threads.message:
I was expecting ohm resistance to ground at <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>...
Where did you measure?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid Damage to <SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_CPU</SIGNAL> <CAPACITOR>C7214</CAPACITOR> - 5v no Boot
threads.message:
I measured at <SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_CPU</SIGNAL> the first time, have just measured <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and its the same.

Does that sound right or am I making a mistake?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid Damage to <SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_CPU</SIGNAL> <CAPACITOR>C7214</CAPACITOR> - 5v no Boot
threads.message:
PPBUS is the same, just separated with miliohms resistor.

If you still have short, is time to check now <CHIP>U7410</CHIP>/20/30.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid Damage to <SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_CPU</SIGNAL> <CAPACITOR>C7214</CAPACITOR> - 5v no Boot
threads.message:
I am getting 2.2 ohms on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> with all <CHIP>U7410</CHIP>/20/30 off. 

I removed them and re-applied individually with no change in ohms.

So currently I have <CHIP>U7210</CHIP>/20 and <CHIP>U7410</CHIP>/20/30 off the board and still have the short.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid Damage to <SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_CPU</SIGNAL> <CAPACITOR>C7214</CAPACITOR> - 5v no Boot
threads.message: Check if any other coil has the same resistance to ground.
